title: Trump Lists Finalists for National Security Adviser
text:
WASHINGTON—President Trump revealed his short list of candidates to be the next U.S. national security adviser, citing a number of current and former administration officials to succeed the recently departed John Bolton.

Speaking to reporters on Air Force One en route to Mountain View, Calif., Tuesday, Mr. Trump said he narrowed the list of contenders to five, for the person who will be his fourth national security adviser. Mr. Bolton left last week over differences with the president on a range of policy matters.

Mr. Trump said finalists for the job are Robert O’Brien, a top hostage-affairs official with the State Department; Rick Waddell, a former deputy White House national security adviser; Lisa E. Gordon-Hagerty, Energy Department undersecretary for nuclear security; Fred Fleitz, who served as chief of staff and executive secretary on the National Security Council last year; and Keith Kellogg, who serves as national security adviser to Vice President Mike Pence.

Keith Kellogg at the White House last year. Photo: Ron Sachs/CNP/Zuma Press

Hours later, White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said in a statement that “the names of candidates mentioned for the NSA position was not the full list, and there are others being considered.” She didn’t provide additional details.

A new national security adviser would take the job just as the administration faces a number of foreign-policy challenges, particularly as it determines how to respond to an attack on Saudi Arabia’s oil industry, which some within the administration have blamed on Iran. The new national security adviser will also take a leading role in finding a solution to the crisis in Venezuela, as well as the president’s efforts to get North Korea to denuclearize.

Write to Vivian Salama at vivian.salama@wsj.com
description: President Trump revealed his short list for a new national security adviser, citing a number of current and former administration officials to succeed the recently departed John Bolton.
